Award.AwardTitle: Polymorphic Duplications in the Evolution of New Genes in Drosophila

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: Gene duplication is a mechanism to generate new genes, an important genetic novelty for evolution of new functions associated with phenotypic variation. How a gene duplicate arises and changes in abundance over time in a species population is unclear. This research aims to understand the genetic mechanisms and evolutionary forces that lead to new gene functions in some individuals in a population and not in others. Using fruit flies as a model, this study applies an integrated approach to address key questions related to the evolution of new gene functions on a population level. First, to determine the frequency of tandem versus dispersed duplications, hundreds of polymorphic gene duplicates, known to be present at intermediate or high frequencies, will assayed for their chromosomal locations and sequences, using florescence labeling and other techniques. Second, to test the importance of evolutionary constraints related to functionality of the gene duplicates, sequence variation and expression patterns of the new gene duplicates will be examined and compared among functional and non-functional sites. Third, the influence of evolutionary forces governing survival and natural selection will be investigated by comparing within- and between-species variation. Together, the results of these experiments will provide important insights into the evolution of new gene functions.

Broader Impacts: This project will generate a large well-characterized dataset of polymorphic duplicates that will be made publicly available. This project will be closely tied to the education of students and the public and will promote education of under-represented ethnic groups in the communities neighboring the University of Chicago. In collaboration with Chicago State University (CSU), this project will initiate a new direction of teaching and research training in molecular evolution for CSU biology students, including opportunities to participate in summer research, to take undergraduate courses about genome evolution, and to engage in related educational activities. In addition, this project will train graduate students and postdoctoral students, thus contributing to their career development as independent scientists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Gene duplication has been shown to be a major source of evolutionary innovation. We seek a transition from an experimental measuring the rate of recent duplicates (1 ~ 20 million years ago) to the understanding of mechanistic processes for the origin of these young duplicates, ranging from underlying evolutionary forces to their functional targets. To do so, we proposed three specific objectives to investigate as intellectual merits: Objective 1. Characterize the PD candidates in D. melanogaster to identify their chromosome locations and gene structures.  Objective 2. Analyze the selective targets of the PDs by examining the expression and the signature of evolutionary forces. Objective 3. Investigate evolutionary mechanisms that govern gene duplication by investigating the evolutionary genetics of the PDs.  We also proposed to have the broader impact of this project by serving two levels of public interests.  First, this project will disseminate the high quality gene duplicate databases to the general research community nationally or internationally in the scientific conferences of genetics and evolution.  Second, developing a valid education procedure in molecular evolution to help train the under-representative students in science. We have generated the project outcomes and findings that addressed above intellectual merits and broader impacts.

 

We have accomplished a number of significant discovers, as are recorded in 24 published articles and a few additional manuscripts in the future. The published articles are in important specific and high profile journals. These significant results are summarized in following sections: 1. We found that species-specific GD in D. melanogaster (<1.4 Mya) evolved essential functions rapidly, forming a genomic proportion similar to those essential ones observed in old or ancient genes.  We also have found that a few genes a few million years old are essential. These works, while overturned an important previous textbook conclusion that essential genes have to be ancient and conservative, have important implications for understanding the diversity of genetic bases that control functional and morphological phenotypes. 2. We found for the first time compensatory sexual antagonisms that evolved with a pair of duplicate genes that recently evolved as a consequence of species-specific duplication in D. melanogaster.  In this case, the new duplicate copy is essential to males but detrimental to females; in contrast, the parental copy is essential to females but disadvantageous to males. With this discover, we found direct evidence for the duplication model to resolve or mitigate sexual conflicts, which were found frequently in Drosophila. 3. We identified a species-specific duplicate in D. melanogaster that evolved essential spermatogenesis function and its parental copy quickly evolved essential oogenesis functions. We further observed that diverged cellular functions of these gene pairs are formed to control separately actin-cone mediated sperm individualization and to form an actin basal cell layer to surround eggs.  These species-specific structural components for spermatogenesis and oogenesis are questioning the conventional thought that they are conserved, providing a new direction for reproductive biological study. 4. In analysis of topological structure of gene expression networks, we found that the new duplicates in D. melanogaster integrated into ancestral networks quickly and a high proportion of them rapidly evolved into a hub structure.  This interpreted why new gene duplicates evolved essential functions so quickly, an important problem raised in the analysis of gene essentiality. 5. We detected significant roles of positive selection on the early stages of new gene duplicate and the evolution gradually slows down with the gene age.  However, our new data from our experiments that knocked down 125 gene duplicates in various ages show that the detected positive selection is not necessarily a consequence of adaptation to changing environments but may reflect a non-adaptive selective process from sex-dependent selection. 6. We found that Drosophila-specific gene duplicates exclusively express in the new lobes of brains.  This suggests the important roles of new gene duplicates to evolution of Drosophila brains and behavior. 7. We have created databases of gene duplicates and their expression patterns and open to the public through website publication (longlab.uchcago.edu). Some of these databases have been published and widely used. 8. Our collaborative research found that long terminal repeats (LTRs) are the most widely used mechanism to generate new retroposed genes and chimeric genes, adding to previous long term conclusion that Line 1 was a mechanism to create retrogenes. This is a breakthrough in the field of retroposition and retrotranspostion, as an anonymous reviewer commented when our report was published in Genome Research recently. 9. We also identified a gene traffic in silkworm in which female-biased retrogenes tend to be copied from the Z chromosome to autosomes. This is forming interestingly a symmetric distribution in evolution to the gene traffic in males. 10. We identified excess of human-specific genes and new gene duplicates are expressed in front-cortex of brains and there is strong evidence that some of these genes were related to cognitive functions.
